metadata.description: AI readiness and competitiveness indices from governments and academic institutions, covering methodology, scoring dimensions, and per-country rankings.
sources: Oxford Insights Government AI Readiness Index 2024
Stanford HAI Global AI Vibrancy Tool 2025
OECD AI Policy Observatory / OECD.AI Index 2024

indices.name: Oxford Insights Government AI Readiness Index
indices.description: Assesses how ready governments are to implement AI in the delivery of public services. Offers a practical tool supporting evidence-based decision-making to help policymakers unlock AI's potential.

methodology.summary: Examines 40 indicators across three core pillars. Vision is scored 0/50/100 (no strategy/upcoming/in place). Other dimensions use normalized composite scoring. Referenced by UNESCO and G20 as official benchmark.

pillars.name: Government
pillars.description: Assesses government vision, governance & ethics, digital capacity, and adaptability for AI adoption in public services.

pillars.name: Technology Sector
pillars.description: Evaluates the maturity and size of a country's technology sector, innovation ecosystem, and human capital for AI.

pillars.name: Data & Infrastructure
pillars.description: Measures data availability, data representativeness, and infrastructure for AI development and deployment.

methodology.data_sources: Multiple international databases, government publications, surveys, and proprietary assessments

indices.name: Stanford HAI Global AI Vibrancy Tool
indices.description: Allows flexible comparisons of 36 countries based on 42 openly available AI-specific indicators. Part of the broader Stanford HAI AI Index Report which tracks AI trends in R&D, investment, regulation, education, and public opinion.

methodology.summary: Uses 42 AI-specific indicators across 8 pillars. Provides default weighting but allows users to adjust weights. Supports both absolute and per capita comparisons. Extended data coverage for 67 countries on selected indicators.

pillars.name: Research & Development
pillars.description: AI journal publications, conference papers, citations, notable AI models produced

pillars.name: Responsible AI
pillars.description: Responsible AI research output, ethics guidelines adoption

pillars.name: Economy
pillars.description: Private AI investment, AI startup funding, number of AI companies, AI patents

pillars.name: Education
pillars.description: AI-related degree programs, university courses, STEM graduates

pillars.name: Diversity
pillars.description: Gender diversity in AI research and workforce

pillars.name: Policy & Governance
pillars.description: AI legislation passed, government AI strategies, regulatory frameworks

pillars.name: Public Opinion
pillars.description: Public sentiment toward AI, awareness surveys

pillars.name: Infrastructure
pillars.description: Computing resources, data center capacity, internet connectivity

methodology.data_sources: Academic databases, government records, investment databases, surveys, patent databases

indices.name: IMD World Digital Competitiveness Ranking
indices.description: Measures the capacity and readiness of 67 economies to adopt and explore digital technologies as a key driver for economic transformation in business, government and society.

methodology.summary: Divides digital competitiveness into 3 factors and 9 sub-factors comprising 59 criteria. Hard data (2/3 weight) and survey data (1/3 weight). Each sub-factor has equal weight (~11.1%) regardless of number of criteria it contains.

factors.name: Knowledge
factors.description: The intangible infrastructure needed to enable the discovery, understanding and building of new technologies

factors.name: Technology
factors.description: The overall context that enables the development of digital technologies

factors.name: Future Readiness
factors.description: The level of preparedness to exploit digital transformation

indices.name: OECD AI Policy Observatory / OECD.AI Index
indices.organization: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD)
indices.description: Provides governments with a robust framework to measure national AI capabilities and track progress in implementing the OECD AI Recommendation. Combines existing AI-specific indicators from the OECD.AI Policy Observatory with newly developed metrics.

methodology.summary: Integrates 28 AI-specific indicators drawn from official statistics, administrative records, surveys, and innovative data sources. Uses population scaling, log transformations, and Min-Max Scaling for normalization. PCA and k-means clustering for data imputation.

components.name: AI Research & Development
components.description: Measuring research output, model innovation, and high-quality software projects

components.name: AI Enabling Infrastructure
components.description: Assessing high-quality digital connectivity, cloud compute availability, and GPU cluster density

components.name: AI Policy Environment
components.description: Evaluating government investment, public-sector AI use, and regulatory sandboxes

components.name: Jobs and Skills
components.description: AI talent attraction, public digital literacy, and supply of specialized AI competencies

components.name: International Co-operation
components.description: Participation in standardization efforts, global research collaborations, and initiatives like GPAI

methodology.normalization: OECD.AI Normalization Process: population scaling, log transformations, Min-Max Scaling (0-1)
methodology.data_sources: Official statistics, administrative records, surveys, innovative data sources, OECD.AI Policy Observatory

indices.notes: The OECD.AI Index was first published in its technical paper format in 2024. Unlike traditional ranked indices, it emphasizes composite scores across components rather than a single ordinal ranking. Full country-level scores are available in the technical paper (Figure 5.2).

indices.name: ITU ICT Development Index
indices.description: Measures progress toward universal and meaningful connectivity (UMC), defined as the ability for everyone to go online under optimal conditions, at an affordable cost, anywhere and anytime. Methodology approved by ITU Member States via Resolution 131.

methodology.summary: Anchored in the concept of Universal and Meaningful Connectivity (UMC). Uses 11 metrics across multiple pillars. In accordance with Resolution 131, only scores are reported; economies are not officially ranked. Methodology approved in November 2023, valid for four years.

pillars.name: ICT Access
pillars.description: Measures fixed and mobile broadband subscriptions, households with internet access

pillars.name: ICT Use
pillars.description: Measures individuals using the internet, mobile broadband usage, fixed broadband usage intensity

pillars.name: ICT Skills / Enabling Environment
pillars.description: Measures digital literacy, mean years of schooling, tertiary enrollment

methodology.data_sources: ITU statistical surveys, national statistics offices, UN agencies
methodology.notes: Resolution 131 stipulates scores only, no official rankings. Average IDI 2024 score: 75 out of 100.

indices.name: Tortoise Media Global AI Index
indices.description: Comprehensive assessment of global AI capabilities across implementation, innovation, and investment. Covers a 5-year data window from 2019 to present. Published September 2024.

methodology.summary: Underpinned by 122 indicators collected from 24 different public and private data sources, and 83 governments. Organized across three pillars (Implementation, Innovation, Investment) and seven sub-pillars. Scores range from 1-100 with 100 being the highest.

sub_pillars.name: Talent
sub_pillars.description: Availability of skilled practitioners in AI solutions

sub_pillars.name: Infrastructure
sub_pillars.description: Scale of advanced computing infrastructure and semiconductor manufacturing

sub_pillars.name: Operating Environment
sub_pillars.description: Regulatory context and public opinion on AI

sub_pillars.name: Research
sub_pillars.description: Quantity and quality of specialist academic and industry research

sub_pillars.name: Development
sub_pillars.description: Development of new AI models and AI application in patents across fields

sub_pillars.name: Commercial
sub_pillars.description: Private sector AI investment, startup ecosystem, and commercial deployment

sub_pillars.name: Government Strategy
sub_pillars.description: Government spending on AI, national strategies, and public computing investments

indices.name: EU AI Watch Index
indices.description: Analysis of multiple indicators related to AI development in EU Member States, with comparisons to the US and China when possible. Monitors industrial, technological and research capacity, and policy initiatives in European countries.

methodology.summary: Contains 22 indicators organized around 5 dimensions. Focuses on EU27 with comparisons to US and China. Analyzes AI landscape, industry adoption, R&D activity, technology enablers, and societal aspects. Country chapters provide detailed policy analysis for each EU member state, Norway and Switzerland.

dimensions.name: Global View on AI Landscape
dimensions.description: Overview of AI activity including publications, patents, and companies

dimensions.name: Industry
dimensions.description: AI adoption by businesses, enterprise AI usage rates, and economic impact

dimensions.name: Research & Development
dimensions.description: R&D activity including patenting, publications, EU funded projects, and collaboration networks

dimensions.name: Technology
dimensions.description: AI as general purpose technology: technological enablers, performance, and standardization

dimensions.name: Societal Aspects
dimensions.description: Diversity in research including gender diversity, higher education offer in AI, and public sector AI use

methodology.scope: EU27 Member States (plus Norway, Switzerland for comparisons)
methodology.data_sources: Eurostat, European Patent Office, Scopus, EU AI investments data, JRC analyses

indices.notes: The EU AI Watch Index was last fully updated in 2021. More recent AI monitoring in the EU is conducted through the OECD.AI partnership and the European Innovation Scoreboard. Country chapters cover all EU Member States, Norway, and Switzerland with detailed policy analysis.
